questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of behavior problems over the past 7 months. The patient has been frequently interrupting his parents when they are speaking with others. He often forgets to complete tasks assigned to him, such as cleaning up toys or taking out the trash and is easily distracted. His parents state that when they speak to him, he often does not seem to listen. The patient has been performing poorly in school, and his parents are scheduled to meet with the teacher next week. Past medical history is notable for a tonsillectomy at age 9. Height and weight are consistently tracking at the 50th percentile. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following would be most useful in identifying the patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Behavioral report from the child’s teacher
Evaluation for maternal alcohol use during pregnancy

questions.solution:
This boy’s inattention, distractibility, and forgetfulness are characteristic of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

ADHD is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent and pervasive inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity. The condition is more common in males than females (3-4:1). Diagnosis of ADHD requires the onset of several symptoms (see below table) before age 12 and impairment in multiple settings (e.g. school and home). Therefore, physicians should provide a patient’s teacher with behavioral rating scales during the diagnostic evaluation to help establish the presence of ADHD symptoms in the classroom setting. For instance, children with ADHD may exhibit inattentiveness and poor organizational skills at school with resultant poor academic performance.

ADHD shows high concurrent comorbidity with other neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorder, specific learning disorders (e.g., dyslexia, dysgraphia), intellectual disability, and tic disorders.



Option Analysis

✅ Behavioral report from the child’s teacher   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Hearing evaluation   :
Incorrect: Hearing impairment can mimic attention-deficit hyperactive disorder. While hearing impairment can cause poor school performance and failure to respond to speech, it would not account for the patient’s difficulty with completing everyday tasks and distractibility. Moreover, this patient does not have any speech deficits, which makes hearing impairment even less likely.   
❌ Genetic testing for FMR1   :
Incorrect: Genetic analysis for mutations in the FMR1 gene can help diagnose Fragile X syndrome, which may present with symptoms similar to attention-deficit hyperactive disorder. Patients with Fragile X syndrome also typically have characteristic physical features, such as a long, narrow face, enlarged ears, and a protruding chin. In contrast, these physical features are absent in this patient.   
❌ Polysomnography:
Incorrect: A polysomnography can be performed in children suspected of having sleep apnea, which can present with difficulty paying attention, daytime sleepiness, and poor school performance. The greatest risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea in children include adenotonsillar hypertrophy and obesity. In contrast, this patient had a tonsillectomy and has a normal BMI for his age, which makes sleep apnea less likely to be the underlying cause of his symptoms.   
❌ Evaluation for maternal alcohol use during pregnancy   :
Incorrect: Inquiring about maternal alcohol use is helpful if fetal alcohol syndrome is suspected. The condition can result in developmental delays and behavioral issues, along with specific physical examination findings, including short palpebral fissure length, smooth philtrum, and a thin upper lip. This patient has an unremarkable physical examination, making fetal alcohol syndrome less likely.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office by her parents for evaluation of irritability. The patient has been having 3-4 temper tantrums each week, which consist of breaking small objects and throwing books and papers around for 30 minutes. The parents describe the inciting event as typically something small such as “being unable to operate the TV remote control.” Additionally, the patient has a baseline irritable mood most days of the week, and as a result, her teachers and classmates have found it difficult to engage with her. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals and physical examination are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) is characterized by recurrent explosive outbursts of intense anger and violence, which can sometimes cause injury to the patient or others. These outbursts are disproportionate to the situation, inconsistent with the patient’s developmental level, and occur at least 3 times per week for at least one year. A unique characteristic of DMDD is that even in between outbursts, these individuals are persistently angry or irritable. Symptoms of DMDD manifest by the age of 10 and can be diagnosed only in individuals between the ages of 6-18.

Treatment of DMDD is complex and typically involves cognitive behavioral therapy to develop the patient’s skills in tolerating frustration and avoiding emotional overreaction. In some patients, treatment with stimulants or antipsychotics may be appropriate.  

Option Analysis

✅ Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Oppositional defiant disorder   :
Incorrect: Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is characterized by a recurrent pattern of defiant and disobedient behavior towards authority figures that do not typically lead to serious violations of social norms. In contrast, this patient has a history of recurrent temper tantrums and baseline irritable mood. These findings are more consistent with those of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder.   
❌ Conduct disorder   :
Incorrect: Conduct disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of violating social norms and the rights of others. These individuals often have a history of stealing, injuring others (including animals), and lying for gain. This patient has no such history.   
❌ Intermittent explosive disorder   :
Incorrect: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) and intermittent explosive disorder are both characterized by severe, angry outbursts. However, in contrast to patients with DMDD who have a baseline mood disorder, patients with IED lack mood disturbances in between outbursts. This patient has a baseline irritable mood.   
❌ Normal behavior   :
Incorrect: This patient’s recurrent outbursts and baseline irritable mood are interfering with her performance at school. These symptoms are not normal behavior and additional efforts should be made to identify the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to recent bedwetting. He was toilet-trained at the age of 3 and has been able to stay dry during the day. However, he continues to have nighttime “accidents” 3-4 times per week. The patient consumes fluids in the morning and afternoon, but not prior to bed. The family recently moved from their home in the city to a suburban neighborhood, and he has experienced difficulty making new friends at school. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 107/68 mmHg, and pulse is 79/min. A complete physical examination is noncontributory. The patient is subsequently trialed on scheduled timed voids overnight and a bedwetting alarm, both of which fail to control his symptoms. The patient is subsequently initiated on a medication that acts as an antidiuretic hormone analog. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Enuresis, also known as bedwetting, is when individuals repeatedly urinate on themselves while asleep. To make this diagnosis, episodes must occur at least twice a week for at least 3 consecutive months in someone older than 5 years of age. Enuresis can be further divided into primary and secondary enuresis.

Primary enuresis is defined by urinary incontinence in children who have never achieved nighttime dryness (no “dry” period for longer than six consecutive months) as well as no underlying medical factors contributing to their incontinence (e.g., diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, urinary tract infection). Secondary enuresis describes new-onset enuresis after a dry period of at least 6 months. Secondary enuresis is typically caused by underlying factors, such as diabetes mellitus or obstructive sleep apnea.

Most children outgrow bedwetting by the time they reach puberty. If enuresis persists, patients are usually treated using behavioral modification techniques, such as restricting fluid intake before bedtime or voiding at scheduled times. Adults can also help children avoid shame and embarrassment via positive reinforcement, by rewarding certain positive behaviors like going to the toilet. If these fail to work, individuals may use a bedwetting alarm or have children sleep on a special pad that sets off the alarm when it becomes wet.

Refractory cases may require the use of medications like desmopressin, which is an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) analog. An alternative is imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant. However, imipramine is usually avoided due to its severe side effects, which include cardiotoxicity, convulsions, and coma.

Option Analysis

❌ Ramelteon:
Incorrect: Ramelteon is a sleep aid that functions as a melatonin receptor agonist, not an antidiuretic hormone analog.   
✅ Desmopressin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Imipramine:
Incorrect: Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant, is an alternative medication used in the treatment of enuresis. However, imipramine is typically avoided due to its severe side effects, which include cardiotoxicity, convulsions, and coma.   
❌ Clonazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines can reduce sleep latency as well as stages 3 and 4 of nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Its suppression of NREM sleep is particularly beneficial in the treatment of somnambulism and sleep terrors since these episodes occur during NREM sleep. However, benzodiazepines have not been shown to be effective in treating enuresis.   
❌ Modafinil:
Incorrect: Modafinil, a dopamine reuptake inhibitor, is a wakefulness-promoting medication used in the treatment of narcolepsy. It has no role in treating children with enuresis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for evaluation of odd, repetitive behaviors. Over the past year, the patient has been blinking excessively, which his parents attributed to dry eyes and allergies. More recently, the patient has been frequently grimacing and clears his throat for no apparent reason. The parents are worried because the patient has been bullied in school for these behaviors. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and an upper respiratory infection that developed several weeks ago. Throat cultures, antistreptolysin O titers, and anti-DNase B titers obtained during this episode were negative. The patient has been meeting all developmental milestones. He performs well at school, and language development is normal. Vitals and physical examination are unremarkable. Considering this patient’s most likely diagnosis, which of the following additional conditions is he at greatest risk for developing?

choices.text: No increased risk of concomitant conditions

questions.solution:
This patient has vocal tics (throat clearing) and motor tics (blinking, grimacing). These symptoms are concerning for Tourette syndrome (TS), which is strongly associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder.

TS is a neurological disorder characterized by motor and phonic tics that develop during childhood. TS is thought to occur due to a disturbance in the cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical (mesolimbic) circuit, which results in disinhibition of the limbic and motor systems. Tics are the clinical hallmark of the condition and are characterized by sudden, brief, intermittent movements (motor tics) or utterances (phonic tics). The diagnosis of TS is based upon clinical symptoms present before age 18. The specific diagnostic criteria can be found in the table below.

Most patients with TS have at least one comorbid psychiatric condition. These may include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (60-80%) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (11-80%). Other comorbid conditions include learning disabilities, oppositional defiant disorder, anxiety disorders, sleep disorders, and mood disorders such as depression.

Treatment for TS involves maximizing the patient’s potential in school settings and social functioning. Habit reversal training is a behavioral therapy that helps in improving and controlling tics. In more severe cases, α2-adrenergic agonists (e.g., guanfacine, clonidine) and neuroleptics (e.g. fluphenazine) can be used to control tics.



Option Analysis

✅ Obsessive-compulsive disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ No increased risk of concomitant conditions   :
Incorrect: Psychiatric comorbidities are extremely common in patients with Tourette syndrome (TS). Comorbidities may include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and oppositional defiant disorder. Some studies suggest that only around 10% of patients with TS have no comorbid conditions.   
❌ Autism spectrum disorder   :
Incorrect: This patient has both motor and verbal tics, which are concerning for Tourette syndrome (TS). Patients with TS often have comorbid psychiatric conditions, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and oppositional defiant disorder. However, TS is not associated with autism spectrum disorder.   
❌ Seizure disorder   :
Incorrect: Seizure disorder has not been shown to be associated with Tourette syndrome.   
❌ Mitral valve stenosis   :
Incorrect: Mitral valve stenosis can be a complication of rheumatic heart disease. Sydenham chorea, an autoimmune complication of Streptococcus pyogenes infection, can present with involuntary, jerky movements, hypotonia, behavioral changes (e.g. emotional lability), and tics. This patient’s negative throat culture and group A Streptococcus titers, however, make this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office by his parents for evaluation of abnormal behavior. Over the past two months, the patient has refused to go to school almost every morning and has already missed several days. He is awake most nights worrying about going to school because he is concerned “bad things” will happen to his parents while he is gone. As the start of the school day approaches, he cries and screams that he “cannot go” and often experiences stomachaches. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient lives at home with his single parent. Height and weight are at the 55th percentile. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 103/66 mmHg, and pulse is 91/min. Physical examination is noncontributory. The physician asks to speak with the patient alone and during this time, the patient repeatedly asks where his parents are and if they are okay. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with reluctance to attend school, tantrums, stomachaches, and fear that adverse events may happen to his parents while he is away. He likely has separation anxiety disorder.

Separation anxiety is a normal developmental phenomenon often present in children from 10 months of age until the early preschool years. In contrast, separation anxiety disorder describes an exaggeration of otherwise developmentally normal anxiety. Patients with a history of childhood parental loss, extended parental absence, and family history of anxiety disorders are at higher risk for developing separation anxiety disorder.

Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by persistent problems with attending school and other activities away from home or attachment figures (e.g., parents, caretakers) due to fear of separation. Children are often worried about the safety of their attachment figures while away. This fear can escalate into tantrums or panic attacks that can adversely affect the patient’s academic, social, and emotional development. Patients may also experience physical symptoms (e.g., stomachaches, headaches, vomiting) before or during separation.

Symptoms need to be present for at least 4 weeks in order for the diagnosis to be made. Several forms of exposure-based cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) are effective in treating this condition.

Option Analysis

✅ Separation anxiety disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Panic disorder   :
Incorrect: Individuals with panic disorder experience panic attacks that are often characterized by intense fear, sympathetic overdrive, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Patients also have fear of developing another attack, which contributes to distress, avoidance of certain stimuli, and/or functional impairment. This child’s anxiety revolves around reluctance to leave his parent in fear of something bad happening, which is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.   
❌ Agoraphobia:
Incorrect: Agoraphobia is characterized by anxiety in situations where the patient perceives the environment to be dangerous, uncomfortable, or unsafe. These situations can include wide-open spaces, uncontrollable social situations, and unfamiliar places. In contrast, this patient’s anxiety revolves around reluctance to leave his parent in fear of something bad happening, which is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.   
❌ Adjustment disorder with anxiety   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder develops as a response to a stressful event (e.g. starting at a new school) and may manifest with a depressed mood, anxiety, and emotional outbursts. However, the diagnosis of adjustment disorder should be avoided when a patient’s condition is better explained by more specific conditions. This child’s anxiety revolves around leaving his parent and is suggestive of a different diagnosis.   
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder   :
Incorrect: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by a chronic, persistent anxiety about many different events/activities and needs to be present for more than six months. This child’s anxiety primarily revolves around leaving his parent and, as a result, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office by his parent for evaluation of abnormal behavior. Over the past year, the patient has refused to go to school almost every morning. As the start of the school day approaches, he cries and screams that he “cannot go.” At school, the patient often has difficulty reading passages from books out loud and writes “random letters” on his assignments. He becomes easily frustrated in the classroom. In addition, the patient frequently confuses the order of words in sentences while speaking. The patient participates in karate after school and enjoys playing with his older siblings and other children in his neighborhood. Growth, vital signs, and physical examination are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has difficulties with reading, writing, and speech at school. He most likely has dyslexia, which is a learning disorder.

Learning disorders are characterized by difficulty learning and developing certain skills for at least 6 months. Examples include dyslexia (difficulty reading), dysgraphia (difficulty writing), and dyscalculia (difficulty with mathematics). Learning disorders may cause poor academic performance, low self-esteem, behavioral problems, and poor social interactions. Nonetheless, an individual's adaptive behavior (e.g., personal care, empathy, memory) is largely unaffected. In contrast to learning disorders, intellectual disability causes significant impairments in both intelligence (e.g., learning, reasoning) and adaptive behavior.

Dyslexia is a learning disorder characterized by specific, isolated impairment of reading and spelling which cannot be explained by delayed development of cognitive abilities or low intelligence. The condition affects around 5% of children and adolescents. Patients with dyslexia demonstrate a pattern of difficulty with word recognition and decoding (i.e. producing sounds associated with letters and words). The condition may also impair the individual’s ability to read and write.

Treatment of dyslexia involves making small modifications to the normal method of instruction that takes the individual’s condition into account. Examples include having text printed in a specific font, untimed tests, and oral testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Specific learning disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Oppositional defiant disorder   :
Incorrect: Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is characterized by a recurrent pattern of defiant and disobedient behavior towards authority figures. In contrast, this patient’s frustration centers around difficulty with reading, writing, and speech, which are more suggestive of dyslexia.   
❌ Age-appropriate behavior   :
Incorrect: Learning disorders should be identified by a parent or school staff as soon as possible. Unidentified learning disorders can contribute to future comorbidities such as anxiety, depression, and worsening academic performance. This patient has significant difficulties with reading, writing, and speech, which are not part of age-appropriate development.   
❌ Autism spectrum disorder   :
Incorrect: Autism spectrum disorder should be suspected in children with impaired social communication, restricted interests, and repetitive behaviors. While this patient has difficulty with speech, he does not exhibit fixated interests or repetitive behaviors and is able to play appropriately with other children. As a result, his symptoms are more likely due to another condition.   
❌ Separation anxiety disorder   :
Incorrect: Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety regarding separation from home or attachment figures (e.g., parents, caretakers). Separation anxiety disorder can manifest with tantrums, panic attacks, and somatic symptoms (e.g., headaches, stomachaches). However, this patient’s reluctance to attend school centers more around his difficulties and frustration with reading and writing. These findings are more concerning for dyslexia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of problems at school. The patient started kindergarten three months ago. Recently, his teacher called his father to inform him that the patient does not speak during class or with classmates. During playtime, the patient chooses to play on his own and does not speak with other children. His father found this news surprising since the patient enjoys singing at home and is talkative with his siblings. The patient has met all developmental milestones and past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient does not speak at school despite being talkative at home. He most likely has selective mutism.

Selective mutism is a condition wherein an individual fails to speak in certain social situations (e.g. school) but speaks normally in other settings. The condition typically develops before the age of 5 but is often not diagnosed until the patient fails to speak in school. As per the DSM-5 criteria, to make a diagnosis of selective mutism, the symptoms must be present for at least one month (excluding the first month in school) and interfere with the individual’s academic, occupational, or social function. Other underlying language disorders (e.g., autism spectrum disorder, social communication disorder) must also  be ruled out before diagnosing a patient with selective mutism.

Selective mutism is highly comorbid with social anxiety disorder, and the two conditions share commonalities with regard to etiologic factors and treatment approaches. Treatment options include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) with increasing exposure to social situations. If CBT alone is insufficient, pharmacological therapies, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), may be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Selective mutism   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Language disorder   :
Incorrect: Language disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty in the acquisition and use of language due to deficits in comprehension and/or production. Common signs include limited vocabulary, sentence structure, and functional use of language. This patient’s ability to effectively communicate with his siblings at home makes language disorder an unlikely diagnosis.   
❌ Childhood-onset fluency disorder   :
Incorrect: Childhood-onset fluency disorder, commonly known as stuttering, is an impairment in the fluency of speech production. In contrast, this patient has a history of not speaking at school despite being talkative at home, which is more concerning for selective mutism.   
❌ Social communication disorder   :
Incorrect: Social communication disorder is characterized by a pervasive difficulty in the social use of verbal and nonverbal communication. In contrast, this patient’s ability to interact socially with his family makes this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Adjustment disorder   :
Incorrect: Adjustment disorder is not diagnosed when a patient’s symptoms meet the criteria for a more specific psychiatric condition. This child’s refusal to speak in school for more than a month meets the diagnostic criteria of selective mutism.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought into the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of abnormal nighttime behavior. Over the past several months, the patient has woken up screaming shortly after going to sleep. These episodes occur 3-4 times per month. During these episodes, the patient is short of breath, crying, and sweating. On several occasions, the patient’s parent felt her pulse and noted it was “racing.” After a few minutes, the patient goes back to sleep on her own. She does not have a recollection of these events the next morning. The family recently moved from their home in the city to a suburban neighborhood. The patient has been meeting all developmental milestones. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/74 mm Hg. Physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Occurs during stage N3 of sleep
REM sleep atonia is lost during episodes
Urinary and fecal incontinence during episodes

questions.solution:
This young girl has been experiencing episodes of autonomic arousal early during sleep. She cannot be consoled, returns to sleep right afterward, and has no recollection of the episodes. These findings are suggestive of sleep terror disorder.

Sleep terror disorder is a type of parasomnia that occurs during stage 3 of nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. The condition is often triggered by stress, fatigue, fever, or sleep deprivation and primarily affects children. Sleep terrors are characterized by marked autonomic nervous system activation. Tachycardia, tachypnea, tremulousness, mydriasis, and sweating are often present. Facial expressions of terror or intense fear are usually present, along with uncontrollable shouting, screaming, and agitation.

The duration of sleep terrors is usually brief, often from less than a minute to several minutes. These episodes cease abruptly, with the child returning to deep sleep. Children often cannot recall the episode; complete amnesia of the event the following morning is typical.

It is important to distinguish sleep terror disorder from nightmares. Unlike sleep terror disorder, nightmares typically occur during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, and individuals are usually able to recall the episode the subsequent morning.

Option Analysis

✅ Occurs during stage N3 of sleep   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Occurs during REM sleep   :
Incorrect: Nightmares occur during REM sleep. Individuals with nightmares are able to recall details from the episode the next day. In contrast, this patient has no recollection of these episodes and, as a result, is more likely to have sleep terror disorder, which occurs during stage N3 of sleep.   
❌ Muscle atonia present during episodes   :
Incorrect: REM sleep is characterized by the loss of muscle tone and paralysis of the body’s voluntary muscles. Nightmares, which occur during REM, are characterized by muscle atonia. In contrast, this patient is likely suffering from sleep terror disorder, which occurs during non-REM sleep and is not characterized by muscle atonia.   
❌ REM sleep atonia is lost during episodes   :
Incorrect: This child has been experiencing episodes of autonomic arousal during sleep, cannot be consoled, but has no recollection of these episodes the next morning. She likely has sleep terror disorder, which develops in the N3 stage of nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. REM sleep is unaffected in patients with sleep terror disorder.   
❌ Urinary and fecal incontinence during episodes   :
Incorrect: Seizure episodes can cause urinary and fecal incontinence. Patients with seizures may experience autonomic system activation and have no recollection of the event afterward. However, this patient’s episodes occur exclusively at night and are associated with crying as well as screaming, which makes sleep terror disorder a more likely explanation of the symptoms.

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the office by her parent for evaluation of “odd behaviors.” The patient has met all developmental and motor milestones over the past year, including walking and playing with toys. However, over the past four months, she has had difficulty walking and sitting up without support. In addition, while the patient used to babble and say single words, she has not spoken much for the past three months. Weight and height are at the 50th percentile. The patient’s head circumference has decreased from the 40th percentile to the 25th percentile in the past four months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 100/67 mmHg, and pulse is 103/min. On examination, the patient is hypotonic and needs to be held by her parent to sit upright. She wrings her hands together repeatedly. An underlying genetic disorder is suspected. Which of the following best describes the normal function of the protein produced by this gene?

choices.text: Transcriptional repression and activation in developing neurons
Targeting proteins for degradation within cells
Detection of DNA damage and regulation of cell cycle progression
Converting nitrogen from peripheral sources into excretable urea

questions.solution:
This patient presents with the loss of motor and language skills, deceleration of head growth, and hand wringing. She likely has Rett syndrome, which is a rare neurological disorder that mostly occurs in young girls and causes severe neurological impairments early in life.

Rett syndrome is caused by an X-linked dominant mutation of the methyl-CpG-binding protein 2  (MECP2) gene, which encodes the MeCP2 protein. Mutations in the MECP2 gene usually occur sporadically. Normally, the MeCP2 protein helps silence other genes. The genes regulated by MeCP2 proteins are particularly important for brain development, specifically to help establish neuronal connections. Therefore, when the brain of a patient with Rett syndrome is in the early stages of development, the low levels of MeCP2 proteins are sufficient for normal brain development. However, as the brain grows more complex, the level of MeCP2 becomes insufficient, and the brain fails to develop normally, resulting in a regression of previously met milestones.

Since males have only one X chromosome, a mutation in the MECP2 gene means they cannot make functional MeCP2 protein. Therefore, males with the mutation typically die in utero or shortly after birth.

Clinically, affected girls initially develop normally and then experience loss of speech, loss of purposeful hand use, decelerated head growth, as well as the onset of stereotypic hand movements (e.g. hand wringing) and gait abnormalities. Additional manifestations include seizures, autism-like features, intermittent breathing abnormalities, autonomic nervous system dysfunction, cardiac abnormalities, and sleep disturbances.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transcriptional repression and activation in developing neurons   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Targeting proteins for degradation within cells   :
Incorrect: Patients with Angelman syndrome have a mutation in the UBE3A gene, which encodes for the ubiquitin-protein ligase E3A (UBE3A) enzyme. UBE3A is involved in targeting proteins for degradation within cells. A mutation in the enzyme leads to the accumulation of unwanted proteins and impaired neuronal development. Patients with Angelman syndrome can present with developmental delay, seizures, and inappropriate laughter. This patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.   
❌ Detection of DNA damage and regulation of cell cycle progression   :
Incorrect: The ATM gene is defective in ataxia-telangiectasia. The gene produces ATM kinase, which is expressed in all tissues in the body. It is involved in the detection of DNA damage and plays an important role in cell cycle progression. Individuals with ataxia-telangiectasia typically present with progressive cerebellar ataxia, spider angiomas, abnormal eye movements, and immune deficiency. While this patient has experienced difficulty with ambulation, she lacks the other symptoms associated with ataxia-telangiectasia.   
❌ Converting nitrogen from peripheral sources into excretable urea   :
Incorrect: The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway that transforms nitrogen to urea for excretion from the body. A urea cycle disorder would manifest in newborns with somnolence and poor feeding followed by lethargy, vomiting, and coma. It would be atypical for a urea cycle abnormality to first manifest with symptoms at the age of 18-months.   
❌ Maintenance of peripheral nerve myelination   :
Incorrect: Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) is a hereditary disease that leads to demyelination of the peripheral nervous system. It can be due to mutations in a variety of genes, including the PMP22, MPZ, and EGR2 genes. CMT presents with a progressive sensorimotor polyneuropathy that results in gait problems, foot deformities (e.g., flat feet, high arches, hammertoes), and scoliosis. However, CMT would not manifest with the loss of language skills or repetitive hand movements.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of unusual behavior. His parents are concerned about his intellectual development and state that he is “quiet” and almost always by himself, both at home as well as in daycare. He plays with toy trains for hours daily. If the toys are misplaced, he becomes enraged and throws tantrums, which involve him banging his head against the wall. The patient was born full-term, and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. Weight and height are at the 55th percentile. During the examination, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician and sits in the corner playing with his toy trains. The physician attempts to take a train from the patient, which causes him to shout, cry, and flap both hands. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with social isolation, repetitive stereotypical movements (e.g., hand flapping, headbanging), and a fixated interest in trains. He likely has autism spectrum disorder (ASD). ASD typically manifests within the first several years of life and is 4 times more common in males than in females.

ASD is a complex neurological disorder characterized by impaired social communication, restricted interests, and repetitive behaviors. Patients with ASD may exhibit findings described in the below table. In addition, these individuals often become distressed when their surrounding environment is changed due to limited adaptive capabilities. Children with ASD also have higher rates of co-occurring language problems, intellectual disabilities, and epilepsy than the general population.



Option Analysis

✅ Autism spectrum disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Rett syndrome   :
Incorrect: Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant neurodevelopmental disorder that occurs almost exclusively in females. Affected patients initially develop normally, but then they gradually lose speech and motor capabilities typically around the age of 2.   
❌ Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder   :
Incorrect: Similar to children with autism spectrum disorder, children with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) may have deficits in social and neurobehavioral skills. Children with FASD also have characteristic facial features, such as short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and a smooth philtrum. In contrast, these facial findings are absent in this patient.   
❌ Landau-Kleffner syndrome   :
Incorrect: Landau-Kleffner syndrome is an epileptic condition that presents with regression in language milestones after normal development. However, this patient does not have a history of seizures, and his clinical features are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.   
❌ Fragile X syndrome   :
Incorrect: Patients with Fragile X syndrome may display autism-like behaviors. However, patients with Fragile X syndrome will also typically have characteristic facial features including a long face, large ears, and a prominent jaw, all of which are absent in this patient.   
❌ Selective mutism   :
Incorrect: Selective mutism is characterized by intact communication skills in certain settings (e.g. home) but not in others (e.g. school). Additionally, restricted, repetitive behaviors, as seen in this patient, are typically absent in selective mutism.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to his physician’s office by his parents for evaluation of behavioral problems. The patient has had multiple issues with police over the past year, including one incident involving robbing a convenience store with friends. He later described the incident as a “prank.” He also has a history of “experimenting” with squirrels in his backyard, which involved developing elaborate methods to injure them. Although the patient’s grades are good, he has been disciplined twice over the past month for blurting out inappropriate words during class. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 109/75 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 14-year-old patient has a history of violent behavior against humans and animals. He feels little regret for his actions. These findings are suggestive of conduct disorder (CD).

CD emerges in childhood or adolescence and is characterized by persistent behaviors that violate the rights of others, such as physical aggression towards people or animals, theft, and property damage. Individuals with CD typically do not feel remorse for their actions.

CD affects around 3% of school-aged children and is twice as prevalent in males compared to females. The etiology of CD is complex and not fully understood but likely involves contributions of both genetic and environmental risk factors. In addition, CD is associated with various neurocognitive impairments, including smaller gray matter volume in limbic regions (e.g., amygdala, insula, orbitofrontal cortex) and functional abnormalities in brain circuits responsible for emotion processing and regulation.

Treatment of CD is complex and primarily involves psychotherapy. Treatment can include cognitive-behavioral therapy to teach individuals to better solve problems, communicate, and handle stress.

CD often persists into adulthood, and individuals with CD are at increased risk for developing antisocial personality disorder (ASPD). To be diagnosed with ASPD, patients must be at least 18-years-old and have evidence of CD before age 15.  

Option Analysis

✅ Conduct disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Oppositional defiant disorder   :
Incorrect:  Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a recurrent pattern of defiant and disobedient behavior towards authority figures. However, patients with ODD do not typically exhibit behavior that significantly violates social norms or violates the rights of others.   
❌ Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder   :
Incorrect: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) and intermittent explosive disorder are both characterized by severe, angry outbursts. Individuals with DMDD are angry or irritable most of the time – nearly every day and in between outbursts. Although this patient has engaged in violent activities, he does not have persistent anger or irritability.   
❌ Antisocial personality disorder   :
Incorrect: To make the diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder, an individual must be at least 18-years-old and demonstrate evidence of conduct disorder before age 15. This patient is 14-years-old and has committed violent acts against humans and animals, which is most consistent with conduct disorder.   
❌ Intermittent explosive disorder   :
Incorrect: Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) is characterized by severe, angry outbursts but a normal baseline in between outbursts. Individuals with IED may become aggressive and violent during outbursts but typically feel remorse afterwards. In contrast, this patient does not feel remorseful for his actions.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parent in winter for a routine checkup. He has missed several previous appointments since the parent was overwhelmed with work and could not take time off. According to the parent, the patient does not interact with other children in the neighborhood and often avoids eye contact with other people. Vitals are within normal limits. Height and weight are below the 10th percentile. The child is not wearing a jacket despite the cold weather outside. He makes minimal eye contact with the physician. Physical examination reveals patches of hair loss on the patient’s head. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. The physician decides to interview the child separately. Which of the following diagnoses is the physician most likely concerned for?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with several signs of neglect, including inadequate clothing (e.g. lack of a coat in the winter), dental caries, malnutrition, and alopecia. Child neglect is harm done to a child by the omission of care – in other words, a failure to provide the care and nurture necessary for a child to grow and be healthy. It is the most common form of child abuse and may result in significant long-term harm.

Physical examination in a child enduring neglect may demonstrate signs of lack of care. The examination may show poor oral hygiene (e.g. dental caries), malnutrition with significant growth failure, untreated diaper rashes, or untreated wounds. In contrast, signs of physical abuse (e.g., bruises, fractures, retinal hemorrhages) may not necessarily be present. Children may also have a lack of trust towards others as well as impaired language and social development.

There should be a low threshold for child neglect screening. The physician should ask the parent(s) to leave the room and subsequently provide a safe environment for the child to talk about their feelings and concerns. The physician should ask direct questions about the child’s safety and if there have been any situations where the child was physically abused. If child neglect is suspected, child protective services should be notified immediately.

Option Analysis

✅ Child neglect   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Conduct disorder   :
Incorrect: Conduct disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of violating social norms and the rights of others. These individuals often have a history of stealing, injuring others (including animals), and lying for gain. This patient’s dental caries, poor growth, and hair loss are more concerning for child neglect.   
❌ Fragile X syndrome   :
Incorrect: Patients with Fragile X syndrome typically have characteristic physical features, such as a long, narrow face, enlarged ears, and protruding chin. These physical features are absent in this patient, and this patient’s dental caries, poor growth, and hair loss are more concerning for child neglect.   
❌ Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder   :
Incorrect: Individuals with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) have severe, angry outbursts and are also irritable and angry in between outbursts. This patient’s dental caries, poor growth, and hair loss are more concerning for child neglect.   
❌ Autism spectrum disorder   :
Incorrect: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) may manifest with social dysfunction, an inability to connect with others, and poor eye contact. However, this patient’s dental caries, poor growth, and hair loss are more concerning for child neglect.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought into the emergency department by his parent following a motor vehicle accident. The parent states they were stopped at an intersection when another car hit hers in the rear. The patient was restrained in a car seat during the accident. At arrival, the patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 95/47 mmHg, and pulse is 109/min. Weight is at the 10th percentile and height is at the 60th percentile. The patient is inconsolable by his parent. Physical examination reveals several bruises over the trunk and extremities at different stages of healing, which the parent attributes to falls that occurred while he was learning to walk. There is significant tenderness over the right leg and any manipulation of the extremity causes pain. Imaging reveals a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This 6-month-old child, who is not yet capable of standing or walking, presents with several bruises in different stages of healing as well as a spiral femoral fracture. These findings are suggestive of child abuse, which demands immediate attention and action.

Children in unstable family situations (e.g., single-parent homes, domestic violence, parental substance use disorders) are at increased risk of enduring child abuse. As soon as child abuse is suspected, a skeletal survey should be performed to evaluate for additional occult fractures. Findings suspicious for child abuse include bruises or fractures at various stages of healing, femoral fractures in non-ambulatory infants, and posterior rib fractures. Additional diagnostic evaluation should include an ophthalmic examination to evaluate for retinal hemorrhages and a head CT to assess for intracranial bleeding.

If a healthcare provider suspects child abuse or neglect, local child protective services should be notified immediately. Management of patients with child abuse entails stabilization, identification, and treatment of all injuries, including a low threshold for hospitalization.



Option Analysis

✅ Child abuse   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Osteogenesis imperfecta   :
Incorrect: Children with osteogenesis imperfecta have a congenital defect in the synthesis of type I collagen. These patients are predisposed to various bone fractures, even in the setting of minimal trauma. Other physical examination findings include short stature and blue sclerae, neither of which are present in this patient.   
❌ Vitamin C deficiency   :
Incorrect: Vitamin C is necessary for proper collagen synthesis and formation. Vitamin C deficiency can result in fragile vasculature and easy bruising. Although this patient has several bruises over the body, the spiral femoral fracture and inconsistent history provided by the parent suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ Rickets:
Incorrect: Rickets is usually caused by vitamin D deficiency. In children, the condition can present with bone pain, deformation, and fractures. Although this patient has a femoral fracture, the presence of bruises in various stages of healing and the parent’s inconsistent story (children do typically begin standing or walking until 9-12 months of age) are concerning for child abuse.   
❌ Accidental trauma   :
Incorrect: Trauma, such as a car accident, can lead to bruising and fractures. However, the bruising would typically be in a specific pattern, such as along the path of a seatbelt. In contrast, this child’s bruising is widespread and in various stages of healing. Moreover, the parent’s inconsistent history should raise suspicion for child abuse. In general, children do not typically begin standing or walking until 9-12 months of age.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s office by her parent due to behavioral issues. The patient has been receiving detention at school for repeatedly talking back to teachers during class. The parent also recalls, “When I ask her to complete simple chores around the house, she gets extremely irritated and argumentative.” Furthermore, she frequently irritates and gets into verbal arguments with her older siblings. When asked why she is behaving this way, the patient states, “It’s not my fault that everyone else is so boring and can’t understand me.” Vitals and physical examination are within normal limits. Urine toxicology is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of nonviolent confrontational behavior towards authority figures. She most likely has oppositional defiant disorder (ODD).

ODD is characterized by a recurrent pattern of defiant and disobedient behavior towards authority figures that does not typically lead to serious violations of social norms. Such behavior often begins in the preschool years but can be initially difficult to distinguish from developmentally appropriate, although troublesome, behavior. Patients with ODD can have strained relationships with parents, teachers, siblings, and peers. Patients also have high rates of coexisting psychiatric comorbidities, such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and mood disorders.

Children with ODD are at increased risk of developing conduct disorder and subsequently antisocial personality disorder during adulthood, both of which are characterized by increasingly anti-authoritative and violent tendencies. Psychotherapy with parents and children together can improve outcomes. One method of therapy aims to develop a child's skills in tolerating frustration and avoiding emotional overreaction. When oppositional defiant disorder coexists with ADHD, stimulant therapy can reduce the symptoms of both disorders.



Option Analysis

✅ Oppositional defiant disorder   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Conduct disorder   :
Incorrect: Conduct disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of violating social norms and the rights of others. These individuals often have a history of stealing, injuring others (including animals), and lying for gain. In contrast, this patient’s history of nonviolent defiance to authority figures is more suggestive of oppositional defiant disorder.   
❌ Normal behavior   :
Incorrect: This patient’s defiance to authority figures is interfering with her performance at school. These symptoms are not normal behavior and additional efforts should be made to identify the underlying condition.   
❌ Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder   :
Incorrect: Individuals with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) not only have severe, angry outbursts but are also irritable and angry in between outbursts. While this patient has a history of argumentative and confrontational behavior, it is primarily targeted towards authority figures (e.g., parents, teachers, older siblings). These findings are more suggestive of oppositional defiant disorder.   
❌ Intermittent explosive disorder   :
Incorrect: Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) is characterized by severe, angry outbursts with a normal baseline in between outbursts. While this patient has a history of argumentative and confrontational behavior, it is directed predominantly towards authority figures (e.g., parents, teachers, older siblings). As a result, she most likely has oppositional defiant disorder, as opposed to IED.
